descriptionList.title: Fuzzy Navigation System for Mobile Robots
descriptionList.detailInfo: This is a navigation system that can guide a mobile robot moving to the desired destination without hitting into obstacles. To test the system, we first build a simple simulation environment using Python. The simulator can allow us to put different shapes of obstacles and tell the robot the readings of its virtual sensors. Then, we use Fuzzy Logic to teach the robot some basic fuzzy rules, for example, "If the obstacle is close to the left, then turn right for a little bit". The outputs of the fuzzy engine are defuzzified and used to drive the robot.

data.title: Smart Road System
data.detail:
This project is an early prototype of a smart road system. There are 4 cameras that cover the whole lab. Each camera is connected to a computer. Using image processing, I can precisely detect the position of the front point and the end point of a car in the image frame. As the cameras are calibrated, those positions can be converted into the world frame. Thus the 3D position and orientation of a given car can be calculated.
To control the mini-car through the Wi-Fi network, we replace the built-in remote controller with Raspberry-Pi. PWM waves are generated and control the servo motor and the DC motor. The 4 computers share information through the Ethernet network, and each of them has a separate Wi-Fi network card and acts as a small base station. To make the mini-car able to roam across different base stations, the network card on the mini-car works in a connectionless way.
The lane-keeping controller is a PID controller. Given the position and status of a mini-car, we can calculate a virtual target position. As the car is moving, the virtual target is also moving. So, the car can run along the lane stably.
We use ROS as our inter-computers communication framework. As all the information is transmitting through ROS, we use Rviz to visualize the status of the system, which is pretty helpful for debugging.
I designed and implemented the entire software system, as well as part of the hardware system.

data.title: A Hand Gesture Recognizer based on Machine Learning
data.detail:
We use HOG, LBP and skin color as the key features. To get a better performance, PCA is used to reduce the dimension. 
In order to detect the position of the hand, we use 3 different sizes of sliding windows to scan the image. Then, a heat-map is generated and the "hottest" location is most likely represent hand.
The sub-image is then fed into the next classifier to classify gestures. 5 different gestures can be recognized, including open-hand, thumb-up, and so on. As you can see, the gesture recognizer is able to tell both the position and the gesture class in a relatively complicated image.
Instead of download training sets from the Internet, we collect hundreds of images by ourselves.

data.title: LLVM Loop Optimization Comparison
data.detail: In this project, I wrote 4 simple C programs, and use Clang with LLVM to compile them with different options. The generated LLVM IR code before and after optimization are compared. The gem5 simulator is used to analyze the time consumption and the cache miss rate. Finally, these optimization techniques are applied to Polybench to make comparisons.

data.title: Tip-over Prevention for Mobile Robots
data.detail: By controlling the heavy manipulator installed on the mobile robot, the Center of Gravity (CoG) can be adjusted. Thus, the stability of the robot can be improved. In this project, I implemented an algorithm to read the IMU sensors and calculate the ideal pose of the robot. The algorithm is tested and verified with V-REP simulator. The simulating code is written in Lua, and the controller program is implemented in Matlab.

data.title: Course Project of Building Intelligent Robot
data.detail: There are 3 PUMA robots and 1 mobile robot. The binocular camera system can detect the position of black cylinders, and guide the PUMA robot arm to pick up and place them on the mobile robot. The mobile robot can localize itself by recognizing AR markers, and navigate to the next position. It can also use infrared sensors to detect and avoid obstacles. All these robots communicate with each other through ROS.

data.title: Club Management System
data.detail: The system has multiple functions including project, budget, and team members managements. The front-end is implemented with React.js, and the back-end is realized with Django. The database is MySQL.

data.title: Coroutine Scheduler
data.detail: Implemented a coroutine library and its scheduler in C. In order to control the registers while a function is being called, the Assembly language is also used. Each coroutine task has the ability to call blocking functions, such as 'sleep' without freezing the whole system. The outputs from each task are transferred to a named pipe to display in another terminal. This project is originally designed for Linux. Then, after fixed a byte alignment problem, it can also run on macOS, as macOS has additional constraints.

data.title: Robotic Goalkeeper
data.detail: Used a camera to detect the rolling tennis ball and predict its track. After the cross point is calculated, commands will be sent to the car-like robot to catch the ball through Bluetooth. The core controller is designed with GUI to visualize the system status.

data.title: Beita App
data.detail: An app that can help students memorize course materials easier. You can either copy and paste your documents, or use the camera to scan it. This app support user-friendly gesture operations, so selecting the important paragraphs is really easy.

data.title: Cobweb App
data.detail: An internal team management tool for Bingyan Studio.

data.title: A Wireless Communication System with Pluto SDR
data.detail: Used Pluto SDR to implement a simple wireless communication system. Realized two communication protocols to support reliable communication: stop-and-wait & sliding window. This system can transmit texts or arbitrary files.

data.title: Ultrasonic Somatosensory Game
data.detail: By changing the distance with your hand and the sensor, players can control the distance between the two read squares. Your job is preventing those squares from hitting the blue bars. The higher scores you got, the faster the bars move. We used a FPGA board (with a IP Core installed) to read the ultrasonic sensor and control the VGA display.
